node.title: [Service] NIT followups to `AddService` in #316
node.body:
## Summary

NIT followups to #316 added in a separate PR to avoid blocking the base PR.

## Type of change

Select one or more:

- [ ] New feature, functionality or library
- [ ] Bug fix
- [x] Code health or cleanup
- [ ] Documentation
- [ ] Other (specify)

## Testing

- [ ] **Run all unit tests**: `make go_develop_and_test`
- [ ] **Run E2E tests locally**: `make test_e2e`
- [ ] **Run E2E tests on DevNet**: Add the `devnet-test-e2e` label to the PR. This is VERY expensive, only do it after all the reviews are complete.

## Sanity Checklist

- [ ] I have tested my changes using the available tooling
- [ ] I have performed a self-review of my own code
- [ ] I have commented my code, updated documentation and left TODOs throughout the codebase

node.title: Add debugging to user settings page
node.body:
It would be helpful to have an endpoint in PL that showed what data we received from the authentication provider. This wouldn't be an everyday requirement, but might help us quickly troubleshoot SSO setup with institution admins.

The User Settings page seemed like a reasonable place to display some additional authn information. This PR adds a "?debug" query flag to the page to enable embedding more information. There is a toggle for this mode at the bottom of the page -- if we want this functionality to be more hidden, we can remove the visible link to debug mode.

Right now it only shows LTI 1.3 authentication data from the session. That still needs to be saved there; either in this PR or a different one.

node.title: Added Additional and Multiple Submission Types for Quest Submissions
node.body:
## What?
I created the models that will allow us to support quests having multiple questions. I also created CRUDL views to allow teachers to create/view/edit/delete questions for quests. For any quest, they can access these views by clicking the new "Edit Questions" button beside the "Edit Prerequisites" button. Finally, I added the functionality for students to submit their answers to questions. 

The new models implement the following ER diagram:

![question_uml](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/2fa687b5-8602-422b-8ebb-760db0f92fe1)

The dashed lines indicate weak relationships, meaning, for example, that a Question cannot exist without a Quest.

## Why?
With these changes, teachers can add multiple submissions to quests. This will make it easier for them to enforce that students answer certain questions, and will make multi-question quests easier for students to understand.

## How?

### Question and QuestionSubmission Models

Everything related to questions, except for how they are used in the quest_manager app, has been moved to a new app called "questions".

❗ **Edit**: I've made a few crucial design decisions since the last review, and these decisions should be evaluated:
#### on_delete behavior for Questions and QuestionSubmissions
- When a Question's Quest is deleted, so is the Question.
- When a QuestionSubmission's Comment is deleted, so is the QuestionSubmission.
- When a QuestionSubmission's Question is deleted, the QuestionSubmission is *not* deleted. This reflects the same relationship that Quests have to QuestSubmissions.

#### `__str__` String representations of Questions and QuestionSubmissions
This was tricky to come up with. The string represenations needed to be different from other string representations. I thought it would make sense for a Question to be represented as `<Quest Name> (<Question Ordinal in Quest>)`, but this format is already used by QuestSubmissions, so I had to come up with something new. Below is what I went with for each object:

```py
class Question(models.Model):
...
    def __str__(self):
        """Return string representation in format of: [Quest Name] ([Question Type] - [Question Ordinal])
        e.g. "Quest 1 (short_answer - 1)" for the first question in the quest with name "Quest 1"
        """
        return f"{self.quest.name} ({self.type} - {self.ordinal})"
...
class QuestionSubmission(models.Model):
...
    def __str__(self):
        """Return string representation in format of: [Comment datetime string] - ([question ordinal])
        e.g. "2022-3-22 1:00PM - (1)" for the first question in the student's quest submission
        If the question is None, return: [Comment datetime string] - (?)
        """
        comment_time = self.comment.timestamp.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %-I:%M%p")
        if self.question:
            return f"{comment_time} - ({self.question.ordinal})"
        else:
            return f"{comment_time} - (?)"
```

#### `next_ordinal(cls, quest)` Question Class Method
Deciding how to handle incrementing ordinal values was tricky. We want to ensure that Questions can be added, deleted, and reordered by teachers, and we want to avoid the problems that occurred with the Quest Submission ordinals. I tried overriding the `save()` method, overriding the `delete()` method, and creating a `reorder(self, new_position)` method, but each of these would have been out of the scope of this task. So instead, we opted for creating a simple `new_ordinal(cls, quest)` class method for the Question model. It is implemented as follows:
```py
class Question(models.Model):
...
    @classmethod
    def next_ordinal(cls, quest):
        """Return the next ordinal value for a question in this quest"""
        max_ordinal = Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).aggregate(Max('ordinal'))['ordinal__max']
        return (max_ordinal or 0) + 1
```

This can be called like so:
```py
from quest_manager.models import Quest, Question

quest1 = Quest.objects.get(...)
next_ordinal_in_quest = Question.next_ordinal(quest1)

next_question = Question.objects.create(quest=quest1, ordinal=next_ordinal_in_quest, instructions='')
```

Go to `src/questions/models.py` for the full implementation of the question models.

### Question CRUDL Views

These views can accessed through the following URLS:
```py
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/', views.QuestionListView.as_view(), name='question_list'),
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/create/<str:question_type>', views.QuestionCreateView.as_view(),
     name='question_create'),
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/<int:pk>/', views.QuestionUpdateView.as_view(), name='question_update'),
path('<int:quest_id>/questions/<int:pk>/delete/', views.QuestionDeleteView.as_view(), name='question_delete'),
```

The full implementations for these views can be seen in `src/questions/views.py`.

### QuestionSubmission Views
With these changes, when a student fills in their responses for a multi-question quest, they will be shown a form for each question. And teachers can view their responses in a dropdown menu underneath their submission comment.

Please see the screenshots below.

## Testing?
- Tests for Question and QuestionSubmission models in `questions/tests/test_models.py`.
    - 23 new tests
- Tests for Question CRUDL views in `questions/tests/test_views.py`
    - 20 new tests
- Tests for QuestionSubmissions in `quest_manager/tests/test_views.py`
    - SubmissionViewTests
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_has_changes`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_question_has_changes`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_question_file_upload`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_question_file_wrong_type_rejected`
    - `test_ajax_save_draft_questions_no_changes`
    - `test_question_submission_form_fields_for_types`
    - `test_students_can_view_past_question_submissions`
    - `test_teachers_can_view_past_question_submissions`
    - `test_student_cannot_see_solutions_or_notes`
    - `test_teachers_can_see_solutions_and_notes`
    - `test_question_submissions_created_for_new_submission`
    - `test_question_submissions_and_comment_not_created_with_existing_submissions`
    - `test_comment_and_questions_deleted_on_drop`
    - SubmissionCompleteViewTest
    - `test_submit_questions`
    - `test_submit_file_question`
    - `test_students_must_complete_required_questions`
    - `test_questions_allowed_file_type`
- Revised tests for QuestSubmissions in `quest_manager/tests/test_models.py` (due to change of draft_text to draft_comment)
    - `test_submission_mark_completed`

## Screenshots (if front end is affected)
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/ef3fa24c-2b03-4834-88cb-cd5b7c239d61)

![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/9b6a734c-6cb9-4e17-894b-67d99f50a10c)

![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/3735f9a0-1207-4afd-b6d1-3595037ba482)

Instructors can see a table of questions, and can easily click to edit or delete them.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/9e963381-da99-447d-9471-14d3caf8a782)

Students can see a list of questions for a quest in their version of the quest detailed view.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/ad23f4f5-f467-4abe-8080-2eeaebd01d7f)

Above the original quest submission field, a formset of question response fields is shown. This is where the student responds to the quest questions.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/5ecc2b47-9242-448b-b2db-e81fda89cea6)

Question responses can be viewed in a table by clicking the "Question Submissions" dropdown.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/a9da9674-4714-496d-9f3e-7e581197454d)

Teachers are shown a different view of question submissions that includes solutions and marker notes:
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/2fb0ba92-0e0f-451e-a313-7a223b2d7d2b)

## Anything Else?
None of the frontend code is setup to look good on mobile devices. I suggest that we create an issue for it, and work on doing that in a brand-new PR, after this one is merged.

I also wanted to mention that a lot of the question content is truncated, since it is difficult to show a lot of content in a table. For this reason, I added tooltips to the question table shown below. I'm not sure how to show this in a screenshot, but the full content of the instructions and solutions can be seen in a bootstrap tooltip by hovering over the content.
![image](https://github.com/bytedeck/bytedeck/assets/11304586/8d6d26d9-b719-4759-8198-bf1c6eca1469)

## Review request
@tylerecouture

node.bodyText: First look over the models.  Nice work! A few notes for you to look at.

Don't override id, id is a default field all model.Models come with that is equivalent to a primary key (.pk).    .id is used all over the place and will be assumed it is a unique identifier for the object.
We don't need to generate primary keys for our models, the default id field works and is what everyone will expect.
should be unique=True
help_text="This may be used as help text for the question type."
None of your string methods are covered by tests.
Thanks for the docstring!
Why null=true blank=true?  What would it mean for a question to not have a type?
What's the difference between solution text and marker notes?

All of these fields should have help_text.  Since these will be user facing models, we want good help text (which by default is the help text that appears in forms) to make use of this feature as easy as possible.
Make sure this sorts the correct direction (lower number first) and ensure there is a test for that.
You added a nice docstring to Quest model, how about nice docstring to Question and QuestionSubmission models? =)

Quite a while ago we had a brief conversation about this: #1304 (comment).
I suppose the idea is that teachers could insert the actual answer to a text-based answer to the question in solution_text, or a file answer in solution_file. And then the teacher would be able to add additional notes in marker_notes.
For example, the instructions would be "what is the best video game?", the solution_text would be the explicit solution e.g. "Tetris", and the marker_notes might elaborate e.g. "The quest hints towards tetris being the best video game".
If this doesn't make sense, maybe either marker_notes or solution_text could be scrapped?

I added help_text for all user-facing fields. I didn't add it for some fields, like the foreignkeys, because I wasn't sure if it would be helpful. Let me know if I should add help_text for them too.
class Question(models.Model):
...
    quest = models.ForeignKey(Quest, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    type = models.CharField(
        max_length=20, choices=QuestionType.choices, default=QuestionType.SHORT_ANSWER
    )
...

My mistake. I was getting Django migration errors, and it was telling me that I had to either provide a default value or allow null values. I changed it so that now the default value is 'short_answer'.
Nice work. I left some comments for you!
This seems weird that the RestrictedFileField is in the models module, when we have a fields module.  That's not your doing but we should move that at some point.

Your human readable labels are identical to what would be inferred by, for example FILE_UPLOAD.label, so seems redundant and unnecessary.  See docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/ref/models/fields/#enumeration-types
Good for now, but once you get this working, please add a description how it handles different questions types.  Maybe a list of relevant fields for each type or similar info.
..."ideal or example solution."
...or example
"This text will appear to the marker, providing additional context and info, if needed.

Since the default is True, help text should describe what happens if UNchecked:
"If unchecked, the student can complete the quest without completing this question." or something like that.
"Questions will be displayed to students in order from lowest ordinal to highest ordinal."

Is this intended for short answer questions?  Short answer should be a CharField with 128 characters or so.  A TextField would be displayed with a Summernote widget for long-answer (with formatting and embedding etc)
If we are not deleting the QuestionSubmission (which I think is a good idea), we'll need to make sure we have good tests covering deleted Questions and ensure those situation are handled.
This could just use self.submission (which would cover the quest.name and the submission ordinal) and require less chaining.

I was under the impression that we'd use the same for both, and that for short answer, we'd limit the length in the form field. How does that sound? I think it would be simpler than adding  additional short_solution_text and short_response_text fields.
I think this has already been done. Not sure what else could be tested. Maybe I could add a test ensuring that the files also aren't deleted or something.

Yep, that makes sense. Short answer can use a charfield widget on the form, and Long answer can use a SafeSummernote. Might need to also look at their processing and display (safe filter or not).
Good idea!
Looks good!
Sure! I'll write down that I have to do that.
You're right. You can do question.get_type_display() and it does the same thing.

Is this because your dev DB has objects with no type, from earlier migrations?  We shouldn't need to provide a type (just as you don't provide a quest).
Might just be a hazard of re-migrating the same thing multiple timeswith different parameters.  Your DB doesn't get reset, so might be good to refresh your db, i.e start a new one on the dev branch, then switch over to this branch and run migrations, so it more closely matches the state of when these migrations would actually happen.
Makes sense!
A couple small code notes.  I will fetch the PR and check out your views/forms.

I don't think the quest name here is necessary.  When would a question be viewed independent of it's quest? The quest context will always be there, (i.e. the question will always be listed with the quest or with a submission so I think it just needs "ordinal - type".  In the detail view we can add the quest name explicitly.
If you think the quest name is still necessary, it should be the part in brackets, not the ordinal and type.
This feels overly complicated.  Why not just Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).last()? Since we are already setting the order via ordinal property?

datetime_created = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)
    datetime_last_edit = models.DateTimeField(auto_now=True)
    ordinal = models.PositiveIntegerField(
        default=1,
        help_text=(
            "Questions will be displayed to the student in order from lowest ordinal to "
            "highest ordinal."
        ),
    )

required = models.BooleanField(
        default=True,
        help_text=(
            "If this field is unchecked, the student can complete the quest without "
            "answering this question."
        ),
    )

marker_notes = models.TextField(
        null=True,
        blank=True,
        help_text=(
            "This text will appear to the marker, providing additional "
            "context and info, if needed."
        ),
    )
done
done
As we discussed, we will save this for later.

I'm not sure. I guess my rational was that doing  Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).aggregate(Max('ordinal'))['ordinal__max'] is getting just a single number from the database. But if  we did Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).last().ordinal, I think it's getting the whole object and then the value afterwards?
Performance gains for this are probably negligible though, so maybe Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).last().ordinal is better since it is more readable?

def __str__(self):
        """Return string representation in format of: [Question Ordinal] - [Question Type]
        e.g. "1 - short_answer" for the first question in the quest with type short_answer
        """
        return f"{self.ordinal} - {self.type}"

I doubt there is any performance difference at all.  1. Django will convert the SQL behind the scenes to make it efficient, and both only hit the database once.  2 .You can't get the Max value of a queryset without looking at all objects in the queryset anyway!
But you got me curious so I asked ChatGPT.  It thinks first() is probably faster for the reasons it gives (grain of salt of course..)
https://chat.openai.com/share/8a774ccf-da5e-45b0-a4d6-8553fbeea62e

My first walk through of the feature. It is looking awesome.  Seems like you have the base structure working well, now just a matter of making it look good and tweaking.  I left a lot of comments for you to look at =)
If I view a quest, it doesn't show the questions anywhere?  Here it shows some questions:

But no indication of the questions anywhere in the Quest, only the old submission instructions.  Questions should be included for staff, similar to how Instructor Notes are.
Why str instead of pk?  str seems too easy to break and we don't use it anywhere else in urls.
Missing whitespace between buttons.  I think you can just add a space after the closing button tag for prereqs button:

The comments app should be independent of other apps.  This should be injected or inserted via the Questions app, not here.
I think you need a template in the questions app for all this, and that's where Submissions would get their comments from.  You can modify the comments/comments.html to add a named block in a convenient location, then you can extend the comments.html template and insert this stuff into the block. (https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/ref/templates/language/)
That will, for example, prevent question stuff from appearing in Announcement comments (or other uses of the comments model elsewhere if implemented in the future)

This is not where the H1 headings go.  All your templates are placing the h1 heading in the wrong location.  Take a look at other templates.  You've removed the block where the h1 heading goes.  Also, these should inherit from their own base template since this is it's own app, not the quest base.html

Put the question type in Quotes like this: Then add
for {{quest name}} or something like that

Instructions and Marker notes should use SummernoteSafeWidget
Solution text should be a short answer, so no need for a big text area.  Can you set it to a text input (shouldn't it be by default? Is this not a CharField?

Similar to the other templates, please fix the heading position to be with the icon, and have the title as:
Question List for {{QUEST NAME}} and have the quest name link to the quest so you can remove button at (1)
(2) Icon means nothing as there is no legend and no hover info.  Remove icon and just put the type name there unless these icons are used elsewhere?  Pencil is generally an Edit icon.
(3) Popup on hover, not on click.  Also, this is similar to how it should appear in the comment/question itself.  Looks good!  Also remove button and change to an icon like info or info-circle
For consistency, change heading of the popup to Marker Notes (not Marker's Notes).

The file upload  "Allowed File Type" should have an option for All/Any filetype as well.  Currently I only see Image, Video, and Media.
Also, Media should have a better name, perhaps just call it Image or Video?
Also, which of these two formats accept an animated GIF?  Both?  How about SVG?  I think more helptext would be beneficial for this field.
Also, if marker notes are empty, the column itself should show "-" or None instead of the popup (i.e. no popup)

The Instructions and Marker Notes should both be SummernoteAdvancedWidgets
The Solution Text for long answer should also be a SummernoteAdvancedWidget, and for short answer should just be a Text (a line or two, not a big TextArea)
Put required on the top.
Add the Quest in small for all the question views, and have it link to the quest.
I'm not sure it makes sense to show answers when staff comment on submissions:
Not sure what's going on here with the double heading:
Huge text area doesn't make sense if you can only have limited characters.  This should be the default widget for a CharField?

Needs an inidication for students what the file-type limitations are:

You can inject this into the help text (via form.py) or however you like.

Table appears to be messed up, missing a column:

Also, the Marker Notes should just be an (i) icon similar to the question list view (see other comment) and appear when you hover.
For the hidden column issue, I fixed this in bootstrap-table-accordion.css. I think you have to do ctrl+f5 to refresh your browser's cached css?

If you are changing CSS files, make sure to also do the cache-busting by incrementing the version number where it is imported into the template, you'll see a ?v9 at the end of the url as a dummy GET parameter (this doesn't change the file name, but most browsers will reload the file anyway because it's a different URL)

As we discussed on slack, this is necessary so that the template can know the type of question before it loads. Otherwise, we'd have to have a whole bunch of JavaScript code to show/hide fields based on the teacher's selection of question type. I created a bunch of buttons that allow for the creation of different types of questions, and it seemed easiest to just have the type be in the URL. That way I can pass it in as follows: Create Short Answer Question Create Long Answer Question Create File Upload Question
You're right. That was a mistake.

I changed custom_common.css to version 1.7, and bootstrap-table-accordion.css to 1.0.
link href="{{ STATIC_PREFIX }}css/custom_common.css?v=1.7" rel="stylesheet">
<link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet"
          href="{% get_static_prefix %}quest_manager/css/bootstrap-table-accordion.css?v=1.0" />
I created a comments_with_questions.html file in the questions app. And now that's what the quest app uses for comments.

node.title: Keep updates and messages in outbox until client is connected
node.body:
This PR is trying to delay updates and messages in case the corresponding client is not yet connected. This will solve problems like this:

```py
@ui.page('/')
def page():
    label = ui.label('Hello world!')

    async def update():
        label.text = 'Hello again!'  # problem 1
        with label:
            ui.run_javascript('alert("Hello from JavaScript!")')  # problem 2
    background_tasks.create(update())
```

Because element updates and other messages are kept in separate queues, there are basically two distinct problems. Messages are already solved, updates are still work in progress.

node.bodyText: I think it would be better to have one loop for each client. Otherwise a blocking client.outbox.send() from one client will affect all the others. Even though a sio.emit() does not wait for a response object from the other side, it still can take time. See my inquiry with ChatGPT: https://chat.openai.com/share/266efdfa-5002-4670-abc5-e9941e437cf0
Wonderful 🥂

node.title: Type call function data and response
Create mouse_from_analog.lua
node.body:
Background:
In some cases like Apple touchpads or inside VMs, mice input is not recognized properly, this hook turns an analog device into a mouse signal. Adapt to your needs.

Usage:
arcan -H hooks/mouse_from_analog.lua <appl>

I assign any copyright I may have for this changes to letoram.

Provenance: 
https://chat.openai.com/share/60c5f152-dd21-41db-9abc-7de49b8363a6

node.title: ODY-334  Iputに単位をつける、ODY-335  インストールアイコンの位置修正
node.body:
# 事前確認(共通)

- [x] PR 前に動作確認をしたか
- [x] ビルドエラー/ESLint エラーは起きていないか
- [x] [開発ルール](https://daydule.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DAYDULE/pages/9765029)を守って実装しているか
- [x] 単体テストが全て OK になっているか（現状はフロントエンドの単体テストを実行できていないため）
- [x] 機密情報を含んでいないか
- [x] 最新の`develop`ブランチを反映しているか

# レビュー優先度（どれか一つ）

- [ ] すぐ見てもらいたい
- [x] 3 日くらいで見てもらいたい
- [ ] 7 日くらいで見てもらいたい

# レビューの度合い

- [ ] コードをぱっと確認してもらいたい
- [x] コードをぱっと確認 & 動作確認してもらいたい
- [ ] コードをしっかり確認 & 動作確認してもらいたい

# レビュワーによる動作確認

- [x] @tom-takeru 
- [ ] @atoook 
- [ ] @kzk27 

# やったこと<!-- このプルリクエストでやったことを書く -->

- inputコンポーネントに単位追加
- フッター追加
- アプリインストールコンポーネントの位置変更

# やらないこと<!-- このプルリクエストでやってもおかしくないけどやらなかったことを書く -->

特になし

# 懸念点や注意点<!-- このプルリクエストにおける懸念点や注意点を書く -->

特になし

# その他<!-- このプルリクエストで上記の項目以外に伝えるべきことを書く -->

特になし

node.bodyText: 編集ボタン押した時にカーソルが当たるように処理追加

input以外をクリックしたときに編集モードをリセットし、単位が挿入されるようにする処理
covertValueToDisplayTextで編集モードの場合も単位がつくようにしようとしたが、処理がうまくいかないのと、あまり入力時に単位がなくても困らないので、この案を採用している

コメントした！
確認お願い🙏

そういえばフッター入れるのすっかり忘れてたね😅　
ありがとう👍
メイン画面の方が、フッターの高さの分だけ縦スクロールできるようになっちゃってるみたいだから、その分だけメインコンポーネントの高さを削ってもらいたい🙏

src/utils/formatting.tsとするやり方に関する参考情報
https://chat.openai.com/share/a9452ad4-6b33-40a9-9e73-6d85fd5bd8fc
外だしした
修正した
LGTM! 🌾

node.title: Add Prompting 101 Tile to independent-ai-topics
node.body:
[Addresses this Asana ticket](https://app.asana.com/0/1201700438643002/1205889394913675/f)

I'd particularly love feedback around the challenge questions and if they seem useful =]

node.bodyText:
Amazingggg work on this, Kelsey!! Reading through this makes me super excited about getting this in front of students. It's gonna be really cool to see the various ways that folx will utilize this tool.
I left a few suggestions; nothing major jumped out at me. Thank you so much!

The last sentence was a bit difficult for me to parse the first time reading it. What do you think of this small change?
  
    
      
        Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            - There are legal considerations if we use AI tools for public work or businesses. Many tools have been trained on massive data sets with text, art and other works scraped from the internet without legal clearance. Unless a tool has been built solely with data that has been given permission to be used for training and generation, it may not be legal to use the art or text generated by an AI tool verbatim. 
          
          
            
            - There are legal considerations if we use AI tools for public work or businesses. Many tools have been trained on massive data sets with text, art and other works scraped from the internet without legal clearance. Using the art or text generated by an AI tool verbatim may be legally restricted unless the tool has been exclusively constructed with data that has been authorized for training and generation.

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            1. Our first step is to visit [chat.openai.com](chat.openai.com) and press the "Sign Up" button to start creating an account. 
          
          
            
            1. Our first step is to visit [chat.openai.com](https://chat.openai.com) and press the "Sign Up" button to start creating an account.

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            5. You can log in with your new account at [chat.openai.com](chat.openai.com) once your email is verified. The first time you log in, you'll be asked to enter your first name, last name, and birth date to verify your age.
          
          
            
            5. You can log in with your new account at [chat.openai.com](https://chat.openai.com) once your email is verified. The first time you log in, you'll be asked to enter your first name, last name, and birth date to verify your age.

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            8. At this point you should be redirected a brand new chat page! We should see "ChatGPT 3.5" at the top, letting us know we are working with OpenAI's 3.5 model. 
          
          
            
            8. At this point you should be redirected to a brand new chat page! We should see "ChatGPT 3.5" at the top, letting us know we are working with OpenAI's 3.5 model.

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            The first number indicates how many versions of the response there are, and the second number is which version of the response we are currently viewing. The arrows are buttons that let us navigate forwards and backwards through the responses so we can see all of the versions.
          
          
            
            The second number indicates how many versions of the response there are, and the first number is which version of the response we are currently viewing. The arrows are buttons that let us navigate forwards and backwards through the responses so we can see all of the versions.
          
          
            
            
          
          
            
            For example, if we generate a response 3 times, when the indicator shows `< 1 / 3 >`, this means we are viewing the first output of the prompt, `< 2 / 3 >` means we are viewing the second output of the prompt, and so on.

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            This incorrect answer is clearly not desired, but we can often get to a correct response for this question by asking the AI tool to show it's work and reason itself to a correct answer. Try out this updated prompt in either the same chat or a new one:
          
          
            
            This incorrect answer is clearly not desired, but we can often get to a correct response for this question by asking the AI tool to show its work and reason itself to a correct answer. Try out this updated prompt in either the same chat or a new one:
I was a bit lost reading this section because I wasn't entirely sure what the prompt to Chat was - is it literally the list of feedback with no other context?

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            When doing our own searching, we also need to be asking ourselves if the sources we’re using to verify information are trustworthy. Anyone can publish anything on the internet, but there are frameworks we can use to ask ourselves questions about a website or source to help us investigate if it may be worthwhile. Once such framework is the SMART Check:
          
          
            
            When doing our own searching, we also need to be asking ourselves if the sources we’re using to verify information are trustworthy. Anyone can publish anything on the internet, but there are frameworks we can use to ask ourselves questions about a website or source to help us investigate if it may be worthwhile. One such framework is the SMART Check:

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            Generative AI tools are very powerful, but at this stage, there are several issues around hallucinations, the cutoff date of their training data, inability connect to the internet to gather new or further information, and inability to share sources from their training data, which together mean that we cannot trust any facts that they state without verification. 
          
          
            
            Generative AI tools are very powerful, but at this stage, there are several issues around hallucinations, the cutoff date of their training data, inability to connect to the internet to gather new or further information, and inability to share sources from their training data, which together mean that we cannot trust any facts that they state without verification.

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            * S
          
          
            
            * S - Scope

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            * M
          
          
            
            * M - Motivation

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            * A
          
          
            
            * A - Authority & Accuracy

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            * R
          
          
            
            * R - Relevancy & Reliability

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            * T
          
          
            
            * T - Timely
That reads much clearer to me too, thanks!
Thanks for catching the number/position swap here, the added example is really helpful. 🙏🏻

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            * T
          
          
            
            * T - Timely

That's exactly what's happening, the prompt is literally just the feedback. Would it be helpful to include a sentence before we show the example around "a prompt can be just data without instructions"?

Edit: I added the line as a suggestion on the PR so it's easier to see/review.
I'm thinking above the feedback when introducing the example, we could start the paragraph with something like:

We're going to look at a prompt that's different from others we've seen – this time we're not going to include any direct instructions on what the generative AI should do. Let's say that we moderate a forum...

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            Let's say that we moderate a forum and want to categorize feedback from our users. We're going start from a zero-shot prompt and iterate on it until we have a few-shot prompt. For our example, we have a list of feedback like:
          
          
            
            We're going to look at a prompt that's different from others we've seen – this time we're not going to include any instructions telling the generative AI what it should do. Let's say that we moderate a forum and want to categorize feedback from our users. We're going start from a zero-shot prompt and iterate on it until we have a few-shot prompt. For our example, we have a list of feedback like:

Suggested change
      
    
    
      
          
            
            If we include no examples, no instructions, and simply submit our list of feedback as a prompt, generative AI tools like ChatGPT will still try to provide a helpful response, likely about how to address these pieces of user feedback. 
          
          
            
            If we include no examples, no instructions, and submit our list of feedback itself as the prompt, generative AI tools like ChatGPT will still try to provide a helpful response, likely about how to address these pieces of user feedback.

node.title: improve documentation Readme
node.body:
Thanks to https://chat.openai.com/share/51b5e459-6956-4591-b8a9-beeae0401063

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- **Documentation**
	- Updated README to reflect new product name, "Instructor", and its features.
	- Added "Get Started in Moments" section for installation guidance.
	- Introduced "How Instructor Enhances Your Workflow" section to highlight key enhancements.
	- Removed "Quick Start" section and relocated "Contributing" section to the end of the document.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

node.bodyText:
Review Status
Actionable comments generated: 2
Configuration used: CodeRabbit UI

Commits
Files that changed from the base of the PR and between 97a8304 and 4eb9f60.


Files selected for processing (1)

README.md (5 hunks)


Additional comments: 3
README.md (3)


1-4: The introduction is clear and concise, providing a good overview of the project.


17-42: The badges and the introductory paragraph provide useful information about the project. The "Get Started in Moments" section is straightforward and easy to follow. The "How Instructor Enhances Your Workflow" section clearly explains the benefits of using Instructor.


222-228: The "Contributing" section is clear and encourages community participation. The link to the issues marked as good-first-issue or help-wanted is a good way to guide potential contributors.

The "Step 1: Patch the client" section provides clear instructions on how to get started with the Instructor. However, it would be helpful to explain what patching the client does in a bit more detail for users who are not familiar with the concept.

Review Status
Actionable comments generated: 2
Configuration used: CodeRabbit UI

Commits
Files that changed from the base of the PR and between 4eb9f60 and a947fb6.


Files selected for processing (1)

README.md (4 hunks)


Additional comments: 9
README.md (9)


1-3: The introduction is clear and concise, providing a good overview of the product and its capabilities. The use of markdown for emphasis is appropriate.


7-13: The badges and links are correctly formatted and provide useful information. However, ensure that the links are up-to-date and lead to the correct destinations.


15-15: The product description is well-written and highlights the key features of the product. It provides a good understanding of what the product does and its benefits.


17-19: The "Get Started in Moments" section provides a clear and concise instruction for installing the product. It's a good practice to keep installation instructions simple and straightforward.


21-28: The "How Instructor Enhances Your Workflow" section clearly outlines the key enhancements provided by the product. The use of bullet points makes the information easy to digest.


30-32: The note on validators is informative and provides a link to a blog post for more information. Ensure that the link is working and leads to the correct blog post.


104-106: The comment from the previous review has been addressed. The "Step 1: Patch the client" section now provides a brief explanation of what patching the client does.


217-219: The "Contributing" section is clear and provides a direct link to issues marked for contribution. This is a good practice as it encourages community involvement.


221-223: The "License" section clearly states the type of license the project is under. This is important information for potential contributors and users.

Note: This review was outside of the patch, so it was mapped to the patch with the greatest overlap. Original lines [34-102]

The "Usage" section provides detailed instructions and code examples, which are very helpful. However, it would be beneficial to add comments in the code snippets to explain what each line does, especially for beginners.

Note: This review was outside of the patch, so it was mapped to the patch with the greatest overlap. Original lines [183-215]

The "Reask on validation error" section provides a good example of how to handle validation errors. However, it would be helpful to explain what happens when a validation error occurs and how the max_retries parameter affects the process.

node.title: fix: disable button on submit
node.body:
<!--
Describe the big picture of your changes here to communicate to the maintainers why we should accept this pull request.

This text will be included in the changelog. If applicable, include links to documentation or pieces of code.
If your change includes breaking changes please add a code block documenting the breaking change:

```
BREAKING CHANGES: This patch changes the behavior of configuration item `foo` to do bar. To keep the existing
behavior please do baz.
```
-->

## Related Issue or Design Document

<!--
If this pull request

1. is a fix for a known bug, link the issue where the bug was reported in the format of `#1234`;
2. is a fix for a previously unknown bug, explain the bug and how to reproduce it in this pull request;
3. implements a new feature, link the issue containing the design document in the format of `#1234`;
4. improves the documentation, no issue reference is required.

Pull requests introducing new features, which do not have a design document linked are more likely to be rejected and take on average 2-8 weeks longer to
get merged.

You can discuss changes with maintainers either in the Github Discussions in this repository or
join the [Ory Chat](https://www.ory.sh/chat).
-->

## Checklist

<!--
Put an `x` in the boxes that apply. You can also fill these out after creating the PR. If you're unsure about any of
them, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! This is simply a reminder of what we are going to look for before merging your code.
-->

- [ ] I have read the [contributing guidelines](../blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and signed the CLA.
- [ ] I have referenced an issue containing the design document if my change introduces a new feature.
- [ ] I have read the [security policy](../security/policy).
- [ ] I confirm that this pull request does not address a security vulnerability. 
      If this pull request addresses a security vulnerability, 
      I confirm that I got approval (please contact [security@ory.sh](mailto:security@ory.sh)) from the maintainers to push the changes.
- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works.
- [ ] I have added the necessary documentation within the code base (if appropriate).

## Further comments

<!--
If this is a relatively large or complex change, kick off the discussion by explaining why you chose the solution
you did and what alternatives you considered, etc...
-->
